example: to remove something, especially without permission :
Has anything been taken ( stolen ) ?
Here's your pen - I took it by mistake .
All her possessions had been taken from her.
I caught him trying to steal my bike.
Someone took their car from outside the house.
He was caught shoplifting by a security guard.
He robbed a bank.
UK When she got home from work, she discovered that her house had been burgled.
Employees pilfering paper, pens, etc. can cost employers a lot.
Are you allowed to take your phone to school?
Could someone bring me a cup of coffee?
Someone's taken my pen.
Can someone please remove this ugly plant?
When you've finished your meal, the waiter takes the plates away.
She opened her bag and took out a small notebook.
to calculate the difference between two numbers :
If you take 4 (away) from 12 you get 8.
"Did you take any money out of my purse ?" "Certainly not!"
When they got divorced , his wife took everything.
They took blood and urine specimens for analysis .
OK, very funny - who took my clothes ?
If anyone found out that I took the money , I'd die of shame .
to move something or someone from one place to another:
The weather forecast said rain , so take your umbrella (with you) when you go out.
The suitcases were taken to San Antonio by mistake .
Take the book up/down to the third floor of the library .
I suggested that he should take her some chocolates /take some chocolates to her ( bring them to her as a present ) .
Are you allowed to take your phone to school?
Could someone bring me a cup of coffee?
Someone's taken my pen.
Can someone please remove this ugly plant?
When you've finished your meal, the waiter takes the plates away.
She opened her bag and took out a small notebook.
Take the vase off the shelf .
Could you take this letter to John , please ?
I took some food from the table .
I took some of the flowers for Mrs Bright.
I took several books with me for the journey .
to accept or have:
Do they take credit cards here?
This container will take ( has room for) six litres .
Which newspaper do you take ( regularly buy ) ?
He continually abuses her, and she just sits there and takes it.
If you think I'm going to take that lying down ( accept it without complaining ) , you're very much mistaken .
I take the/ your point ( accept the argument ) , but I still don't think you should have gone.
They were charged with accepting illegal contributions.
She offered him the job and he took it.
I asked him to marry me and he said yes.
Thank you - I'd like to take you up on your offer.
He offered her the microphone but she wouldn't take it.
Get ready to take hold of the baton as the next runner approaches.
He snatched the letter out of my hands before I could read it.
The car was stolen from right outside our house.
A thief pinched his wallet and phone.
Federal agents seized two computers.
used when you want to mention something as a particular example of what you are talking about:
I've been very busy recently . Take last week , I had meetings every night after work , except Friday .
If you take someone or something to be something, or if you take someone or something for something, you accept or believe that they are that thing:
These creatures are generally taken to be descended from primitive fishes .
to not be able to deal with an unpleasant situation :
I can't take it any more. I'm leaving .
accept or refuse the offer completely :
That's my final offer - you can take it or leave it.
Do you usually take a morning / afternoon break ?
I took this new job because I felt that the career prospects were much better .
The director took a risk in giving the movie's main role to an unknown actor .
She took a few spoonfuls of soup but left her main course untouched .
He took a drop in salary when he changed jobs .
to move in order to hold something in the hand(s):
Can you take this bag while I open the door ?
He took my arm and led me outside .
Take an egg and break it into the bowl .
He took hold of the plant's root and pulled .
The baby took my finger in its tenacious little fist .
Take my hand as we cross the road .
Each player takes three cards .
The doctor had to take my shoulder and click the joint back into place .
He took my arm and guided me to the bar .
to go somewhere with someone, often paying for that person or being responsible for them:
We're taking the kids to the zoo on Saturday .
I took my elderly parents to look at some new houses .
Will you take me swimm ing tomorrow ?
I have to take my mother to the doctor today.
I offered to go with him to the police station.
Can you come to the hospital with me?
Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult.
My husband usually drives the kids to school.
Can you give me a lift into town?
to show someone how to get to somewhere by going there with them:
Let me take you to your room .
to go to a social event with someone:
Who's taking you to the dance ?
As a special treat , I'll take you to my favourite tea-shop.
I had to get up early to take her to the airport .
If he gets any worse I'll take him to the doctor's.
Three days after the birth , Paul and Sandra took their precious bundle of joy home .
I took my two-year old nephew down to the beach with his bucket and spade .
to travel somewhere by using a particular form of transport or a particular vehicle , route , etc.:
I always take the train - it's less hassle than a car .
She took the 10.30 flight to Edinburgh.
If you take the road on the left , you'll come to the post office .
We took a bus to Mexico City.
From Heathrow, you can take a taxi .
I took the 6.30 train to Manchester.
Why don't you take the train to Paris ?
We took a flight to Denver .
to need:
Parachuting takes a lot of nerve .
Transitive verbs take a direct object .
His story took some believ ing ( was difficult to believe ) .
to wear a particular size of clothes or shoes :
What size shoes do you take?
If something takes a particular time , that period is needed in order to complete it:
The cooking process only takes ten minutes .
How long does this paint take to dry ?
It took us all day to drive home .
to act or happen over a short period of time :
I'm just going to the shops - I won't take long .
to need a long time :
Broken bones always take time to heal .
They took two hours to discuss the plans and considered it time well spent .
It took a lot of courage to do what she did.
The insurance company took months to settle my claim .
The jury took four days to reach a verdict .
This recipe takes four cloves of garlic .
to measure something:
Nurses took my temperature and blood pressure .
to swallow or use a medicine or drug , especially in a regular way:
Take this medicine three times a day .
Do you think she takes drugs ?
used to talk about the way in which someone likes to have a particular drink :
Do you take milk ?
He takes his coffee black .
She takes her tea with lemon .
How do you take your scotch ? With water ?
I take my coffee strong with a dash of milk .
to do or perform :
Shelley is taking ( studying ) economics at university .
The Archbishop took our service of thanksgiving .
Mr Marshall takes us for ( teaches us) physics .
used with many nouns to make a verb phrase that is equal in meaning to the related verb :
I think we'll take a break ( we'll stop for a break ) there.
If you're tired you should take a rest ( you should rest ) .
I always like to take a walk ( to walk ) after lunch .
I usually take a nap after lunch .
Who takes this class on Tuesdays ?
I agreed to take Nicola's aerobics class for her next week .
I'm going to take some French lessons .
After the next song , we'll take a break .
to think about something or someone in a particular way:
We're taking the bomb threats very seriously .
to understand something in a particular way:
I was just teasing him, but he took it the wrong way.
I'm not sure whether to take that as a compliment or an insult .
She gave a nod , which we took to mean that she agreed .
to have or come to have a particular feeling or opinion :
He doesn't take any interest in his children .
Don't take any notice of the cameras .
She takes offence too easily .
They took pity on the stray cat and fed it.
I take the view that fuel should be heavily taxed to reduce road use.
to surprise someone:
The sudden noise took her by surprise .
She took offence when we offered to help her.
Don't take any notice of what they say.
She never took any notice of her critics .
He takes the view that children should not be allowed in pubs .
I took pity on her and bought her some clothes .
to receive money from sales or as payment for entrance to an event :
The show took an astonishing $100,000 in its first week .
The restaurant took a lot of money that night .
How much do you usually take in an evening ?
to get possession of something or someone:
Rebels ambushed the train and took several prisoners .
The Liberals need just 200 more votes to take the seat from Labour .
With these wins , the Democrats have now taken the House back from the Republicans.
Centre-left parties look set to take power .
Adam , I'd like you to take control of the aircraft now.
His party took control from the Communists.
UK We'll take a lot of Labour's vote over the issue of fox hunting .
The terrorists have taken hundreds of hostages .
The soldiers were taken behind enemy lines .
to write:
I hope you're all taking notes .
in baseball , to let the ball go past without trying to hit it:
The pitcher had not thrown a strike so I decided to take a pitch .
He was taking all the way on that pitch .
to work or perform as expected :
These new plants haven't taken - they don't like this dry soil .
money that is received from sales or as payment for entrance to an event :
The box office take was huge for the new show.
the filming of a scene ( small part of a film ) :
This scene needed ten takes before we felt it was right .
an opinion about something:
We'd love to hear your take on this issue .
a version of something that shows someone's attitude towards it:
The restaurant offers a new take on traditional French cooking .
to move something or someone from one place to another:
Please, take me with you!
It may rain , so take your umbrella .
The suitcases were taken to Madrid by mistake .
I thought I'd take her some chocolates .
I take home about $200 a week .
to remove something:
Here's your pen - I took it by mistake .
A radio was taken from the car .
To take someone's life is to kill someone:
The fire took her life .
to accept something, or to receive something willingly :
I tried to phone him, but he refused to take my call .
Does this restaurant take credit cards ?
Take this medicine three times a day .
I can take three more people in my car .
It's a girls ' school that has now started taking boys .
Bob took a lot of criticism for his decision .
I refuse to take responsibility for what's happened .
to think of someone or understand something in a particular way; perceive :
I took him to be more honest than he really was.
The police are taking the robberies very seriously .
In the dim light I could have taken them for brothers .
I'm not going to forge his signature ! What do you take me for?
Take is sometimes used to introduce an example of what you mean :
It's been really busy . Take last week - we had meetings every day .
to hold something:
He took my arm and led me to my seat .
Can you take this bag while I open the door ?
to catch , win , or get possession of something:
Rebels ambushed the train and took several prisoners .
My roses took first prize at the flower show.
to have as a necessary condition ; need:
Parachuting takes a lot of nerve .
I take a size 9 shoe .
Transitive verbs take a direct object .
It didn't take much persuasion to get her to go with us.
How long does this paint take to dry ?
Broken bones always take time to mend .
If something takes forever , it happens very slowly :
In rush-hour traffic , it takes forever to get home .
to do something:
I've started taking piano lessons .
The government urged both sides to take steps to end the strike .
Take is used with many nouns to make a verb phrase:
We can't delay any longer - we have to take action ( to act ) .
In the evening I like to take a walk ( to walk ) .
If you're tired , you need to take a nap ( to sleep ) .
to take effect means to start working :
The medicine should take effect quite quickly .
If you take turns , you and other people do the same thing, one after the other:
The mothers in our group take turns driving the children to school .
to measure something:
Better take the baby's temperature - she may have a fever .
to have or cause to have a particular feeling or opinion :
He takes little interest in current events .
She takes offense too easily .
To take someone by surprise means to do something that is completely unexpected :
His sudden proposal took her totally by surprise .
to cheat someone:
You paid $500 for that thing? I think you got taken.
to write information provided by someone or something:
Take notes as you read .
Journalists took down every word he said during the interview .
to make a photograph of someone or something:
We took lots of pictures of the new baby .
to travel on something to get from one place to another:
I always take the train .
Take the road on the left to get to my house .
the filming of a small part of a movie :
That scene needed ten takes before they got it right .
the amount of money received from an activity :
The box office take has been huge for the new show.
a particular feeling , opinion , or reaction :
What's your take on the new proposals for new health care ?
to subtract one number or amount from another:
You'll need to take $2,000 from the $8,000 to allow for tax .
to remove something or someone from somewhere :
What are we left with after we take off our costs ?
I asked for her name to be taken off the list .
They decided to take him off the job and assign him to another department .
The police took away all of the files for investigation .
to accept or receive something:
Do you take credit cards ?
We're taking 5,000 orders a day .
Top executives will take a 10% pay cut .
He took a job as salesman in a local company .
Are you going to take the job if you get offered it?
to receive money from sales or as payment for something:
They took an astonishing $100,000 in their first week .
The company will make money by taking 5% from each bet .
to buy or choose something:
The good news is that they have decided to take 200 units a year .
50% of our total production is taken by just three customers .
to need something:
It takes determination to succeed in a new business venture .
if something takes a particular amount of time , that time is needed in order to finish it:
They estimated that the project would take about 6 months to complete .
to have the necessary qualities or abilities to do something:
Have you got what it takes to be in charge of a department ?
If you don't have what it takes, you're not going to last long .
used when you are offering something to someone to say that you will not improve your offer :
And that's our final offer . Take it or leave it.
to be involved in something with other people :
Most of the board members took part in the discussions .
to think carefully about a situation or event and form an opinion about it, so that you can decide what to do:
When markets touch new highs , investors need to take stock .
I am currently taking stock of our position .

to need a lot of time :
It's going to take time to get this department running smoothly again.
money that is received from sales or as payment for something:
The players now get 75% of the take.
Tour operators had come to rely on the commission from insurance to increase their take.
Last weekend's take was down over 50%.
to accept money for helping someone to do something illegal :
They vowed to punish officials on the take.
They plotted out the area and drew up plans before taking it over.
The two players alternately take new edges, one edge per move.

to look at someone or something and then look again because you suddenly recognize him, her, or it or notice that something unusual is happening :
I did a double take - I couldn't believe it was her.
a delayed surprised reaction at seeing someone or something:
With her hair cut short and dyed red , I did a double take at first.
A double take is necessary.

The theme of the piece involves two people who walk past each other in the street, notice each other, do a double take , and instantly fall in love.
to fill an amount of space or time :
This desk takes up too much room .
Too much of this report is taken up with out-of-date numbers .
Half the letter is taken up with her complaining about her neighbours .
Most of the garage space is taken up with his music kit .
to start doing a particular job or activity :
He's taken up the position of supervisor .
Have you ever thought of taking up act ing ?
Patti took up ( continued ) the story where Sue had left off.
to start an official job :
The minister took up office in December .
I'm thinking of taking up tai chi .
He took up embroidery to pass the time .
to discuss something or deal with something:
The school took the matter up with the police .
I'd like to take you up on your sales figures for June .
A leading law firm took up his case .
to make a piece of clothing , such as a skirt or trousers , shorter
how much people start to use or accept a service , or sometimes a product , that has become available to them:
We are calling for government action to improve the take-up of state benefits .
to begin to do something:
I'm not very good at golf - I only took it up recently .
to discuss or manage something:
The school plans to take the matter up with the parents .
to fill space or time :
This desk takes up too much room .
My day is completely taken up with meetings .
to shorten clothes :
This skirt is too long - I'll have to take it up.
to fill an amount of space or time :
Getting his business started has taken up all his time .
to start doing a new job or activity :
She takes up her new post on December 1.
to accept something:
To take up this offer , you must apply in writing by end March 2012.
I'm happy to take him up on his challenge .
to discuss or deal with something in a formal way:
If you have a problem , you should take it up with the manager .
I took the matter up with the bank .
the degree to which people start to buy or use a product or service that has become available :
It is hard to know what the take-up of the new flat-rate service will be.
It's been a raging success , with more than 90% take-up.

a piece of writing or speech , especially on the internet , giving someone's personal opinions about a topic , usually strong opinions that have not been carefully thought about and that many people are likely to disagree with:
He wants to give us his hot take on how feminism has gone too far .
There have been many hot takes on the ad, some praising it and others lambasting the company for becoming political .

There are many hot takes about what the film gets wrong , or what it gets right .

to start feeling unwell ( not well) , or to start suffering from a medical condition :
She suddenly took ill and returned to Germany to undergo surgery .
He was admitted to hospital yesterday after being taken ill .
Six men working at the site were taken seriously ill .
Alice took ill and died six weeks later .
Several hundred people were taken ill with the E. coli bug .
Her husband was taken dangerously ill with a fever .
The singer , who has a history of heart trouble , was taken ill after coming off stage on Wednesday .
to remove something, especially clothes :
He took off his clothes and got into the shower .
After the poisoning scare , the product was taken off the shelves /the market ( removed from sale ) .
He took off his shoes to cool his sweaty feet .
When he took off his hat , we saw that he was completely bald !
Oops - I forgot to take the price label off your present .
She took off her rings to do the washing-up , and now she can't find them.
The doctor told me to take off my shirt so he could listen to my chest .
to spend time away from your work :
He took two weeks off in September .
I need to take some time off to see my mother .
I took the whole summer off to work on my book .
We're planning to take some time off at Christmas .
If an aircraft , bird , or insect takes off, it leaves the ground and begins to fly :
The plane took off at 8.30 a.m.
The plane took off three hours late.
When should we expect to take off?
to suddenly start to be successful or popular :
Her singing career had just begun to take off.
With all that publicity , the business really took off.
His career really took off after that concert .
to suddenly leave somewhere , usually without telling anyone that you are going:
When he saw me, he took off in the other direction .
to copy the way a particular person speaks or behaves , or the way something is done, usually in order to entertain other people :
She's really good at taking people off.
the moment when an aircraft leaves the ground and begins to fly :
Night take-offs and landings are banned at this airport .
a piece of acting or writing, etc. that copies the way a particular person speaks or behaves , or the way something is done, usually to entertain other people :
It was the best take-off of the prime minister that I have ever seen .
to remove or get rid of something:
He took off his shirt and shoes and jumped in the lake .
After the poisoning scare , the product was taken off the market .
(of an aircraft ) to leave the ground and fly :
The plane took off on time .
infml To take off is also to leave suddenly :
When he saw me coming, he took off in the other direction .
to suddenly become popular or successful :
The new product really took off among teens .
to use a period of time for a purpose that is different from what a person usually does:
I've decided to take next semester off and travel and write.
to suddenly start to be successful :
She became an ethical financial adviser ten years ago, just as green investing began to take off.
He taught for years before his writing career took off.
to suddenly increase in value or amount :
The shares took off, climbing more than 130%.
The time to protect your finances from inflation is now, before prices really take off.
to have a period of time away from work :
After the business trip she took a few days off.
I am definitely looking forward to taking some time off.
to reduce a price by a particular amount :
Being too near a train track could take thousands off the price of a house .

a humorous copy of the speech , manner , or style of someone, esp . someone famous :
He does a great takeoff of Kermit the Frog .
the moment when an aircraft leaves the ground and starts to fly :
Night takeoffs and landings are banned at this airport .
the total amount of money that a government collects in tax :
With a slowing economy there's a lower tax take.

an act of making someone or something look silly :
He told me I'd won and I thought it was just a piss-take.
an act of copying someone else's behaviour and manner in a humorous way:
He did a piss-take of Fiona.
to take someone or something to the house , apartment , country , area , etc. where they live :
I wanted to take the kitten home with me.
We ordered a taxi to take us home .
They can take home half of the fish they catch .

to decide how to deal with someone or something, or what argument or opinion to give about something:
The courts should take a tougher line with ( punish more severely ) violent offenders .

a rude way of telling someone to go away:
The guy kept pestering her, and finally she told him to take a walk .
to make a journey by walking , especially for enjoyment :

the process of doing something, especially when dealing with a problem or difficulty :

This problem calls for swift action from the government .
Action to prevent the spread of the disease is high on the government's agenda .
So what's the plan of action? ( What are we going to do?)

something that you do:

I asked him to explain his actions.

This was considered to be an act of war.
That's the last thing you should be doing if you're pregnant.

Their evil deeds must not go unpunished.
a physical movement :
I'll say the words and you can mime the actions.
It only needs a small wrist action ( movement of the wrist ) to start the process .

things that are happening , especially exciting or important things:
I like movies with a lot of action.
In her last novel , the action ( the main events ) moves between Greece and southern Spain.
There were several police vans and a lot of activity in the area.
I couldn't find her with all the hubbub going on.
I miss the bustle of the big city.

What was the reason behind this sudden flurry of activity?
It's usually quiet in the shop, but occasionally we have a sudden burst of activity.
a style of film in which a lot of exciting and often violent things happen :
His filmmaking style blends action, horror , and comedy .
The action genre is often assumed to appeal more to men.
at the place where something important or interesting is happening :
A journalist has to be where the action is.
The movie provides plenty of thrilling action while delivering a political message .

Her latest film is the staple offering of action and comedy which we have come to expect .

the effect something has on another thing:
They recorded the action of the drug on the nervous system .
Accumulations of sand can be formed by the action of waves on coastal beaches .
The action of market forces means that the cost of something rises if demand for it rises and the amount available remains constant .
His many years of research made him an expert on the action of snake venom .
The distinctive landscape has been formed by the action of running water on the limestone .
The project will study the action of various drugs on the human body .
fighting in a war :
He saw action in the trenches .
Her younger son was killed in action.
A soldier or other member of the armed forces who is missing in action cannot be found after a battle or other military action, so it is not possible to say if they are dead or alive . :
The ceremony honoured those who were missing in action.
the way something moves or works :
We studied the action of the digestive system .
The car has a very smooth braking action.
a legal process that is decided in a law court :
The book was halted in South Africa by a threat of legal action.

to do something to deal with a particular problem or matter :
I'll just run through the minutes of the last meeting , raising those points that still have to be actioned.
the process of doing something, or something done, esp . for a particular purpose :
Quick action in calling the fire department saved many lives .

the way something moves or works , or the effect it has on something else :
The heart's action in regulating blood flow is critically important .
a process in a court of law to correct a wrong by which a person or group claims to have been hurt :
She brought an action against the hospital for negligence .
the process of doing something, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation :
The report urged industrialised nations to take further action to cut their budget deficits .

decisive / drastic / prompt action
The committee was spurred into action by the threat of government cuts .

something that you do, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation :
Industry analysts said the company's actions cannot control market prices .
He said that employees must be held accountable for their actions.
important things that are happening in a market , etc.:
Fund managers let themselves be carried away by the favorable market action of the shares .
a legal process that is decided in a court of law :
He threatened legal action to recover the property .

to begin working to make an idea or a plan happen or be successful :
We need to put these plans into action in measurable ways , so that employees regain a sense of control over their lives .
a way of dealing with a problem or difficult situation , or achieving something:
The Board will devise an action plan to address the problems at the plant .
involvement in something successful that someone else has started :
It's one thing to be a staff attorney and quite another to be an equity partner getting a piece of the action.
to do something to deal with a particular task , problem , or plan :
Some of the conclusions and recommendations of the report can be actioned straight away.
to move along by putting one foot in front of the other, allowing each foot to touch the ground before lifting the next:
I walked home .
A cat was walking along the top of the fence .
He walks two miles to work every morning .
The baby has just learned to walk.

He marched right in to the office and demanded to see the governor.

She ambled down the street, looking in shop windows.
to go with someone to a particular place , for example because you want to protect them from danger , or show them the way:
He offered to walk her home /to the station .
to take an animal , especially a dog , for a walk:
She walks the dog for an hour every afternoon .
someone who seems to be a human form of disaster , encyclopedia , etc.:
You broke another pair of glasses ? You're just a walking disaster !
We'd better walk a bit quicker - it's going to take forever if we go at this pace .
We walked along the beach collecting small crabs in a bucket .
He walks with a limp .
We were just walking along, chatting .
I walked backwards towards the door .
to not be charged with a crime , or to be allowed to leave a court after being found not guilty of a crime :
If police don't get the right evidence , he'll walk.
to suddenly leave a job or other situation because you have not been given what you want :
Pay essential workers $650 a week or we walk.
"Get real or we walk" UK warns Brussels as Brexit trade deal talks resume .
You give me twenty percent discount on the price or I walk.

In cricket , if a batter ( the player who tries to hit the ball ) walks, they choose to leave the field without waiting for the umpire ( the person who makes certain that the rules are obeyed ) to make a decision about whether they are out ( their turn to bat is finished ) :
He nicked an outswinger to the keeper and walked without waiting for the umpire to lift his finger .
The batter refused to walk, even though all the fielders knew that he had hit it.

in baseball , to receive four balls outside the hitting area and be allowed to go to first base , or to throw the ball outside the hitting area four times so that the batter is allowed to go to first base :
The first batters either missed or walked.
He would have had a perfect game , except he walked a batter in the final inning .
to pass or win something, such as an exam or game , easily :
She'll walk the interview - the job is practically hers already.
a journey that you make by walking, often for enjoyment :
He went for a walk around the block to get some air .
Gentle exercise , like taking short walks, can give you more energy .
They went on a ten-mile walk to raise money for charity .
Every afternoon she takes her grandfather out for a walk.
a path or route where people can walk for enjoyment :
Do you know any nice walks around here?
a way of walking:
He has a strange waddling sort of walk.
walking speed :
She slowed the horses to a walk.
a journey that takes a short time , five minutes , ten minutes , etc. when you walk:
The school is only a five-minute walk away.
in baseball , an occasion when a batter is allowed to go to first base after the pitcher has thrown the ball outside the hitting area four times
I went for a walk to try to sober up.
I always like to take a walk after lunch .
Shall we brave the snow and go for a walk ?
It says in the guide that this area of the countryside offers some of the best walks in England .

to move along by putting one foot in front of the other, or to move a distance in this way:
I walked home .
We just walked past a famous actress .
They walked all around Chinatown .
I walk to work every morning .
It's not that far - you can walk it in half an hour .
We must have walked miles today.
To walk someone to a particular place is to walk with the person until the place has been reached :
He offered to walk her home .
To walk an animal , esp . a dog , is to bring it outside with you to walk.
an act of moving along by putting one foot in front of the other, or moving a distance in this, esp . for pleasure or exercise :
He went for/took a walk around the block .
to treat someone badly :
The unions accused management of walking all over their staff .
to stop working because you are angry or unhappy about something:
Autoworkers walked off the job after the unions failed to reach an agreement over pay .
to be forced to leave your job because of something bad you have done:
The expenses scandal gave several ministers no option but to walk the plank .
to do the things you have said you would do, especially when you reach a position of power :
Business groups are waiting to see if the incoming Governor will walk the talk on promises to boost the state's economy .
to do the things you have planned and promised to do:
The country has yet to see whether the new leader can walk the walk.
used to refer to the job you do or the part of society you belong to:
We employ people from all walks of life .
I'd walk past a corner and everything was suddenly different.

Someone was creeping around outside.

They spent the day trekking through forests.
We spent the afternoon strolling around Budapest.
A huge crowd strolled down Fifth Avenue in the Easter Parade.
Will you join us for a stroll in the park?.

Lorries trundle through the narrow lanes.

They trudged wearily through the snow.
He ambled over to the window.

Hurry up! Stop dilly-dallying!

The blue and white balloons floated skywards.
I got out of bed and walked slowly to the door.
Shock and disbelief slowly turned to anger.
Go slower! I can't keep up.
We're stuck in slow-moving traffic.
Shut the door quickly.
They are easy hikes, done at a slow pace.
You only have to hit a pedestrian at a slow speed to kill them.
The economy grew at a slower rate during the second half of the year.
We walked steadily past the crowd.
His work has been improving steadily all year.
A cat's diet should always be changed gradually to avoid digestive upsets.
Little by little, we're getting results.
It's a lot easier to understand if you do it step by step.
My eyesight has got progressively worse over the years.

These words are adverbs or adverbial phrases that mean at a slow speed or rate. The most commonly used word for this is slowly . You can also use the word slow in combination with other words to describe a thing that happens slowly. I got out of bed and walked slowly to the door. Shock and disbelief slowly turned to anger. Go slower! I can't keep up. We're stuck in slow-moving traffic. The opposite of slowly is quickly . Shut the door quickly. For more opposites of slowly , see the article at fast . You can say that something moves or happens at a slow pace or at a slow speed , or that something changes, increases, develops, etc. at a slow rate . They are easy hikes, done at a slow pace. You only have to hit a pedestrian at a slow speed to kill them. The economy grew at a slower rate during the second half of the year. Steadily means moving or happening in a smooth and regular way, not fast. We walked steadily past the crowd. His work has been improving steadily all year. You can say that something happens gradually if it happens or changes slowly, over a long period of time. Little by little can also be used A cat's diet should always be changed gradually to avoid digestive upsets. Little by little, we're getting results. If you do something step by step , you do it one thing at a time, in a fixed order, and without hurrying. It's a lot easier to understand if you do it step by step. Progressively is a more formal word than gradually . It is often used with comparatives. My eyesight has got progressively worse over the years.

If someone or something moves at a low speed or takes a long time to happen, you can call that person or thing slow . Things that happen or are done slowly happen at a slow speed. You can also talk about moving slowly , or getting slower .
If you walk , you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other.
stroke of ill luck stroke of luck stroke with the fingertips stroking stroll stroller strolling strong strong and supple
The boy wandered the neighborhood, looking for his dog. The college student wandered through Europe during the summer.
The little stream wanders through the woods.
The goat wandered from the yard and never came back.
